title: An integrated model of the effects on fitness of positively selected, conserved, and nearly neutral sites in sexual populations and the population-optimal mutation rate
authors: Irlam, G.
abstract: Positively selected, conserved, neutral, and nearly neutral sites have often been analyzed in isolation. Here, an approximate integrated model of the fitness effects of these classes of sites in sexual populations is developed and analyzed. Within this framework, it is shown that the aggregate fitness effects associated with positively selected sites need not be negligible, even when such sites are rare, and that nearly neutral sites can contribute a substantial component of the total genetic load. The framework defines the latent load as the genetic load associated with positively selected sites that are destined to fix but for which beneficial alleles have not yet established. The germline spontaneous mutation rate that maximizes the geometric mean of population mean fitness is predicted, under the model, to occur when the mean latent load is approximately equal to the mutational load. This population-optimal mutation rate differs from the minimal mutation rate predicted by purely microevolutionary considerations that focus on individual-level selection. It is hypothesized that, over macroevolutionary timescales, species-level processes such as differential extinction may bias the mutation rates of surviving species towards the population-optimal value. The model provides a unified framework for assessing the combined fitness effects of positively selected, conserved, and nearly neutral sites, and highlights the potential macroevolutionary importance of the latent load in shaping the long-term evolution of the mutation rate.

title: Oncogenic MAPK pathway activation induces a congenital and progressively lethal rare neuropathy in mice
authors: Marechal, E.; Aldea, D. A.; Quintana, P.; Mondielli, G.; Bernard-Marissal, N.; Moreno, M.; El Yazidi, C.; Broucqsault, N.; Delague, V.; Weiss, L.; Barlier, A.; Etchevers, H. C.
abstract: RASopathies, rare congenital syndromes affecting skin, heart, brain and skeletal systems, often include peripheral neuropathy of unknown origin. Although RASopathy gene variants are familiar proto-oncogenes after birth, the causal relationships between timing and specific pathological outcomes remain unclear. This study examined how a mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) effector, Braf, causes peripheral neuropathy. Targeting the oncogenic Braf(V600E) variant, found in mosaic RASopathies, to cells having expressed myelin protein zero (Mpz) in mice triggered a degenerative neuropathy evoking type 1 Charcot-Marie-Tooth syndrome, with pre-weaning onset of hyperplastic nerves, hindlimb weakness, and unexpectedly reduced body size. Constitutively active Braf expanded a Jun+ Schwann cell repair state, impairing myelination by mature Schwann cells. Patient-derived iPSCs bearing the BRAF Q257R variant, associated with cardio-facio-cutaneous syndrome, failed to differentiate into mature Schwann cells, instead exhibiting transcriptional profiles associated with progenitor or repair states. These findings suggest that somatic mosaicism may contribute to unresolved genetic heterogeneity in human neuropathies and enlarge the candidate gene list. They also reveal a MAPK-dependent mechanism by which neural crest-derived Schwann cells regulate both body growth and peripheral nerve homeostasis..

title: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation in Alzheimer's Disease: Long-term impact
authors: AGGARWAL, A.
abstract: The goal of this work was to integrate results from clinical trials related to transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) treatment of Alzheimers disease (AD) into a machine learning model of the disease to understand its impact on disease progression over a decade. tDCS is a new emerging treatment modality for AD. The impact of tDCS has so far been only sparsely studied in AD patients over a short duration in small sample sizes. Since AD is a progressive disease, it is useful to know about the impact of tDCS over a longer duration and predict the duration and site of treatment. This paper integrates limited data from tDCS treatment of AD patients and extrapolates it to a decade using the AD prediction model (ADPM). Based on this, it provides guidelines for best site and duration of treatment for a patient with AD.

title: Cytokines mediate increased endothelial-leukocyte interaction and brain capillary plugging during CAR T cell neurotoxicity
authors: Park, L.; Tsai, Y.-T.; Hu, R.; Lim, H.-K.; Faulhaber, L. D.; Burleigh, K.; Faulhaber, E. M.; Bose, M.; Draper, I. H.; Smith, S. E. P.; Shih, A. Y.; Hirayama, A. V.; Turtle, C. J.; Annesley, C. E.; Gardner, R. A.; Gustafson, H. H.; ZHENG, Y.; Gust, J.
abstract: CAR-T cells treat cancer, but also cause systemic cytokine release and immune effector cell associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS). In an immunocompetent mouse model, we show by in vivo two-photon imaging that CD19-CAR T treatment causes brain capillary plugging by circulating CAR-T cells and other CD45+ leukocytes, as well as cortical hypoxia. This is accompanied by increased endothelial ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 expression in the brain capillary-venule transition zone, where most of the capillary stalls occur. In the mouse model, circulating CAR-T cells strongly upregulate integrin 4{beta}1 affinity to VCAM-1, but not affinity of integrin L{beta}2 to ICAM-1. Blockade of integrin 4 but not integrin L improves locomotion behavior. In vitro, human brain microendothelial cells upregulate ICAM-1 more than VCAM-1 in response to TNF, IFN-{gamma}, and IL-1{beta}. In a 3D brain human microvessel model, treatment with TNF and IFN-{gamma} is sufficient to induce adhesion of CAR T cells under flow conditions, which is blocked synergistically by antibodies against integrins 4 and L. Finally, patients with the highest levels of TNF and IFN-{gamma} also have the highest blood levels of soluble ICAM-1 and VCAM-1, which in turn correlate with ICANS. Integrin 4 but not L increases in CAR-T cells after they are infused into patients. Combined data from patients, mouse models and in vitro microvessels indicate differential regulation of interactions of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 with their respective leukocyte integrins. Overall, our study supports the hypothesis that cytokine-driven upregulation of endothelial-leukocyte adhesion is sufficient to induce acute, reversible neurotoxicity.

title: Single-nucleus transcriptomics reveals convergent effects of THC exposure and Reelin signaling on nucleus accumbens maturation in adolescence
authors: Zuo, Y.; Libster, A.; Gupta, A.; Liaw, L.; Formoli, N.; Sun, D.; Turner, A.; Iemolo, A.; Telese, F.
abstract: The nucleus accumbens undergoes extensive maturation during adolescence, but how drug exposure and genetic vulnerability interact to shape this process remains poorly understood. Here, we used single-nucleus RNA sequencing to examine the effects of chronic adolescent tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) exposure and reduced Reelin signaling in mice. THC produced broader transcriptional changes than Reelin haploinsufficiency, particularly in medium spiny neurons (MSNs). Analysis of cell-cell communication identified a THC-sensitive signaling program in which inhibitory interneurons were the principal receivers of MSN-derived signals related to axon-guidance and synaptic maturation. Despite the dominant effect of THC, both perturbations converged on shared gene networks linked to human genetic risk for substance use and psychiatric disorders. These effects were strongest in a population of immature neurons that we confirmed are generated in the adolescent nucleus accumbens and decline in adulthood. These findings show that adolescent THC exposure and Reelin signaling converge on transcriptional programs that regulate late neuronal maturation in striatal circuits.
